description: From Middle English rethorycal, rethoricalle, rethorycall, from rethorik, rhetoric (noun) or Latin rēthoricus, rhētoricus, from Ancient Greek ῥητορικός (rhētorikós, “concerning public speaking”).

entries.meaning: Part of or similar to rhetoric, the use of language as a means to persuade.
examples: A rhetorical question is one used merely to make a point, with no response expected.

entries.meaning: Not earnest, or presented only for the purpose of an argument.
(education, dated) A study or exercise in rhetoric.
